title: Configuration settings
body: How are the configuration settings ordered? Also a list of all available configuration settings(i presume most of it is documented already)? Spent almost 3 hours the other day just trying to get sessions working only to realize later that i had not placed app.use(express.session()) in the right order(before app.use(express.methodOverride()) ). Maybe a simple doc on ordering configuration settings? :)

title: possibly cache dynamicHelpers for a single request.
body:
Setting a dynamic helper will call the function that sets the helper each time a template is rendered.
Meaning that if you have layout.jade and content.jade they get set twice in one request.

I don't really see a usecase where this would be needed and for big projects with many templates and many helpers this could hurt performance.

The way I see it, there are 2 and a half options:
1) Leave it like it is.
2) Cache the helpers in req or somewhere else where they are removed as soon as the request is handled.
2b) Provide an option for non-cached helpers if someone really needs them.

title: Regression test suite via examples git
body:
The examples git repo would be a great point to add some unit tests with expresso and have some regression tests on a functional layer while developing. 

Why this is good? 
1. regression Test Suit on a feature level avail- 
2. Could be deployed to different architectures/linuxes so functionality over these osses is the same 
3. The examples would work always ;) 

What to do? 
1. Write Tests for the specific examples 
2. Integrate each of the examples in a build script / CI System
3. Document how to work against these systems

title: Partial collection array-ish support
body: support anything array-like

title: Added local() to request
body:
Hi there,

express is cool.  I'm writing an app that uses route chaining via next().  I didn't see an obvious way to set state on the request so that my first route handler could set a variable that I could reference in subsequent handlers.

I added a local() function on request for this.  It's similar to param() but only gets/sets variables that you define.

Not sure if this is a patch more appropriate to add to Connect, but let me know what you think.  

Tests included.

thank you!

-- James

title: SSL support?
body:
Suppose I want every request to be forced to use SSL. This is easily done as part of the core Node.js API, [server.setSecure](http://nodejs.org/api.html#http-server-157), but I can't figure out how to do this in Express, or for that matter in Connect.

What's the best way to do this? A Connect middleware, perhaps?

so lets have this as well:


title: Actual BODY of a POST
body:
Hey,

Is there a way to get the actual body of a POST request? It seems that I can only extract it it it's urlencoded body params... yet, in the contecxt of the protocol I'm working with, it's a full XML document that is posted in the BODY.

Thanks

title: Tall, fixed-position TOC on guide
body:
Because the table of contents on http://expressjs.com/guide.html is `position: fixed`, the entries near the bottom are hidden on short screens (e.g. netbooks).  Adding something like `#toc { overflow: auto; }` would help.

Many thanks,

-Ben

title: express.cache prevents redirects from finishing
body:
I'm not quite sure what the problem is, but even the most simple "response.redirect('http://google.com')" fails to flush to the browser when express is set up with:

express.cache({ lifetime: (5).minutes, reapInterval: (1).minute })

(Logger logs the returned 302, but the browser never sees it)

This is w/ express@1.0.0rc2

title: Multiple Set-Cookie headers
body: will be an issue with connect as well

title: (Feature Request) Named routes
body:
The idea here is to have a Single Source of Truth for my routes.  So for example:

```
app.get('myRoute', '/foo/:bar', function() { ... });
app.routes.myRoute.path(2) // => '/foo/2'
app.routes.myRoute.path({bar: 'baz'}) // => '/foo/baz'
app.routes.myRoute.url({bar: 37}) // => 'http://example.com/foo/37'
```

Alternatively, `app.verb` could return a route object, which could be made available through exports.  I'd also be happy to work on this feature.

title: Error: EISDIR, Is a directory
body:
Installed Express on Ubuntu 10.04, getting the following:

```
$ express ExpressTest
$ node ExpressTest/app.js

fs:189
  var r = binding.read(fd, buffer, offset, length, position);
                  ^
Error: EISDIR, Is a directory
    at Object.readSync (fs:189:19)
    at Object.readFileSync (fs:99:17)
    at Module._loadScriptSync (module:435:37)
    at Module.loadSync (module:306:10)
    at loadModule (module:251:12)
    at require (module:374:12)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/home/kolanos/Web/JsTests/ExpressTest    /app.js:6:15)
at Module._compile (module:426:23)
    at Module._loadScriptSync (module:436:8)
    at Module.loadSync (module:306:10)
```

What am I doing wrong? Not finding anything on Google for "EISDIR, Is a directory"...

title: view cache control
body:
Currently caching is deferred to the engine, which is not ideal. I had begun
abstracting jade's rendering to return a compiled function, however it ended up
slowing down the renderer greatly, but this is something I would like to revisit in the future.

title: About layout.ejs
body:
About layout.ejs example:
--------------- layout.ejs -----------------

```
<head>
   <title> MY TITLE </title>
</head>
<body>
    <%- body%>
</body>
```

---

I was able to control the other it?
Example:
--------------- layout.ejs -----------------

```
<head>
   <title><%- title%></title>
</head>
<body>
    <%- body#mydiv %>
</body>
```

---

title: Express Executable Fails On Directory Tuple Creation on Linux
body:
If you run

express

on Linux (Ubuntu Karmic in my case), the attempt to create the javascripts, stylesheets, and images folders fails.

However, if you simply execute from a shell

mkdir -p {javascripts,stylesheets,images}

it works fine.

Of course, the Express executable works fine on a Mac, but this does not work on Linux.
